Gator Engineering Newsletter • Spring 2015
Dear Alumni & Friends,

It has been an exciting spring semester here at the College of Engineering. We recently graduated over 1,000 new Gator Engineers across five separate commencement ceremonies. Our new president, Kent Fuchs—an engineer himself—attended some of our undergraduate ceremonies. He spoke to the importance of an engineering education and of the programs and institutes we have in place here at the college that help prepare our students for the workplace and the world. Gator Engineering has recently garnered national attention from the White House, the National Science Foundation, the United Nations, national investors and more—as you'll read below. These accolades demonstrate our commitment to becoming one of the best engineering schools in the country, alongside the university's efforts to secure a spot amongst the nation's top 10 public institutions.

We wish you a wonderful and relaxing summer and hope to see you back on campus for our reunion this fall. It will be during Homecoming weekend—details to follow in the weeks ahead.

Warm regards,

Cammy R. Abernathy
Dean, UF College of Engineering
Featured Stories
College one of 10 named in White House STEM initiative »
The Brain Computer Interface group in CISE gets media attention »
Technology & Innovation

Cybersecurity experts develop lie detector for computers, help UF become a National Center of Excellence
Kevin Butler and his team of graduate students recently developed breakthrough techniques to establish a computer's identity using a USB port and consumer devices. Read more »

BME students and industry partner create new startup to help capture rare cells
Senior engineering students and faculty at UF are partnering with biotech cell and gene therapy company Morphogenesis to design an advanced, fully automated cell separation system capable of capturing rare cells—such as stem cells. Read more »
Programs & Curriculum

Leading Biotech firm invests $1M into BME with focus on regenerative medicine
BioD's commitment will be used to establish an endowed term professorship on top of bolstering collaborative research. Read more »

Newly refurbished UF Training Reactor comes back online
After receiving upgrades to the tune of $3 million—mostly from the U.S. Department of Energy—the UFTR came back online this spring for the time since 2007. Read more »

CPaSS receives NSF award for innovative nanoparticle research
UF's Center for Particulate and Surfactant Systems (CPaSS) was awarded the 2015 Alexander Schwarzkopf Prize for Technological Innovation. Read more »
People

New CISE Chair Announced
Juan Gilbert, Ph.D., the Andrew Banks Family Preeminence Endowed Chair and current associate chair for research, has been named chair of the Department of Computer and Information Science and Engineering. Read more »

Distinguished Alumnus and Achievement awardees address the class of 2015
Gator Engineering alum Jim Allchin, an early pioneer at Microsoft, and Henry Upjohn, a door manufacturer who has created a strategic partnership with our hurricane researchers, were both honored at our spring commencement ceremonies. Read more »

Radiation expert and associate dean appointed to U.S. delegation to the United Nations
Wesley Bolch will travel to Vienna this June to serve as a member of the U.S. delegation to the United Nations Scientific Committee on the Effects of Atomic Radiation (UNSCEAR). Read more »

Engineering professor awarded UF's highest honor
Distinguished Professor Jose Principe was named the University of Florida's Teacher-Scholar of the Year. This award is considered to be UF's highest honor. Read more »

Civil alumnus honored with public service award
The Florida Engineering Society and the Florida Institute of Consulting Engineers honored State Representative Lake Ray with the Governor A.W. Gilchrist Award. The award celebrates engineers who bring honor to the engineering profession through their civil works. Representative Ray earned his B.S. in civil engineering from UF in '81. Read more »
Student Engagement

UF Engineering Innovation Institute student's startup secures funding
Last summer they were one of seven startups featured in the Office of Technology Licensing's Celebration of Innovation. This year, Comm-N-Sense, founded by EII student Adam Kinsey (BSEE '12), is doing business with a new name, and has secured a new round of funding. Read more »

ISE student's startup wins GAIN's FastPitch
Sheldon Barrett and his startup, Cocovana, won the Gainesville Area Innovation Network 6th Annual FastPitch. His invention, the Coconut Twist, offers an easier way to open a coconut. Read more »
In Memoriam

Gene Hemp (Dec. 6, 1938–Apr. 27, 2015)
“He served the college, the university and the Florida university system in so many capacities, always with selfless distinction.” Read more »

Robert “Bob” Ramey (Dec. 14, 1918–Mar 7, 2015)
Ramey was an associate dean of UF College of Engineering, a professor of electrical engineering, as well as computer and information science, the founding chairman of the Computer and Information Science Department, and associate director of the Engineering & Industrial Experiment Station. Read more »

Robert Dean (Nov. 1, 1930–Feb. 28, 2015)
Dean was known around the world for his coastal engineering research and beach nourishment techniques. He became a graduate research professor at UF in 1982 and then chair of the Department of Coastal & Oceanographic Engineering in 1992. Read more »

Kevin Powers (Dec. 7, 1951–Jan. 15, 2015)
Besides his numerous scientific and technological achievements—he was the site director of the National Science Foundation's Center for Particulate and Surfactant Systems—Kevin’s caring attitude, especially toward students, was unparalleled. Read more »
Powering the New Engineer

There has never been a greater opportunity, nor a greater need, to grow an innovative engineering workforce to advance our state, and society as a whole. Powering the New Engineer is our contribution to help UF become a Top 10 public institution, and to drive the state to become a center for high tech development.
Make a Gift Now

Powering the New Engineer is a renaissance approach to engineering education and research - interdisciplinary, dynamic, and focused on innovation and discovery, with a human centered approach. Our curriculum is infused with leadership training and a willingness to use technology to revolutionize how we teach. From this, a new engineer is born. We hope you will join us in Powering the New Engineer.
Go to:
eng.ufl.edu/about/powering
We are Powering the New Engineer.
